abstract.p: Letter by Daniel A Biederman of Bryant Park Restoration Corp defends commercial ventures in park to offset maintenance costs and allow New York City to use its scarce funds for its other 1,500 parks (S)

block.p: Re ''Paradise Lost, Again,'' by Fred Kent (Op-Ed, Sept. 16):

Contrary to the article's suggestion, the relationship between fashion and Bryant Park is good for the public. Bryant Park is entirely financed by private sources, like the payments for use of the park by the fashion shows and the circus. This financing allows New York City to use the Parks Department's scarce funds for its 1,500 other parks.
Re ''Paradise Lost, Again,'' by Fred Kent (Op-Ed, Sept. 16):

Contrary to the article's suggestion, the relationship between fashion and Bryant Park is good for the public. Bryant Park is entirely financed by private sources, like the payments for use of the park by the fashion shows and the circus. This financing allows New York City to use the Parks Department's scarce funds for its 1,500 other parks.

Commercial sponsorships are often shunted to off-peak times. The park presents scores of free cultural events open to the public: jazz and classical concerts, dance performances, poetry readings, athletic clinics and a free Monday night film series. We invite New Yorkers to bring their lunches to the park and see for themselves that it's open to them.
DANIEL A. BIEDERMAN Executive Director Bryant Park Restoration Corp. New York, Sept. 21, 2000
